byline.contributor: Shaila Dewan reported from Dothan, Ala., and Andrew W. Lehren from New York.
byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and ANDREW W. LEHREN

abstract: New York Times investigation reveals pretrial diversion, policy put in place nationwide to help first-time and low-risk offenders avoid criminal record, is often used in Alabama's Wiregrass Country as way for those with money or political favor to avoid criminal charges; Henry County Dist Atty Douglas A Valeska has used policy as way to cement political control over area (Series: No Money, No Mercy).

headline.print_headline: An Alabama Prosecutor Sets the Penalties and Fills the Coffers
headline.main: Alabama Prosecutor Sets the Penalties and Fills the Coffers

snippet: In the city of Dothan, one man’s grip on the criminal justice system has exacted a steep price for many....
lead_paragraph: In the city of Dothan, one man’s grip on the criminal justice system has exacted a steep price for many.
